title: Veteran cop wins $19million compensation after bosses told him he was too gay to promote
text:
St. Louis County police Sgt. Keith Wildhaber, pictured last week, has been awarded a total of $19million in compensation after being told he was too gay to promote (Picture: AP)

A veteran police sergeant whose boss told him he was too gay to promote has been awarded $19million compensation.

Sgt Keith Wildhaver from St Louis County Police Department successfully sued his employer for discrimination after a jury agreed he’d be unfairly passed over for promotion.

At a hearing on Friday, he was awarded $1.9million in actual damages and $10million in punitive damages for the discrimination part of his lawsuit.

Wildhaber was handed a further $990,000 in actual damages and $7million in punitive damages for retaliation, KDSK reported.

The cop joined St Louis County PD in 1994 after four years in the armed forces. But in 2014, St Louis County Board of Police Commissioners member John Saracino reportedly told Wildhaber that ‘the command staff has a problem with your sexuality.’

Wildhaber joined St Louis County PD in 1994, but was told in 2014 that his sexuality had prevented bosses from promoting him. He was moved to night shifts in a remote area after filing a discrimination lawsuit in 2016 (Picture: AP)

Saracino is said to have added: ‘If you ever want to see a white shirt (a reference to a promotion) you should tone down your gayness.’

Wildhaber filed a discrimination suit in 2016, and within a month had been moved from day shifts in a buzzing precinct to overnight hours in a remote area.

Explaining the decision to find in favor of Wildhaber, a jury foreman told the court: ‘We wanted to send a message.

‘If you discriminate, you are going to pay a big price. … You can’t defend the indefensible.’

And Wildhaber’s lawyers said they were ‘ecstatic’ about the ‘historic verdict.’

A statement issued by his attorneys continued: ‘His bravery and courage in standing up for what is right should be an inspiration for employees everywhere.

‘Justice was served in this trial, and no client could be more deserving than Keith.

‘The jury acted as the conscience of the community and spoke loud and clear in its verdict.’

Wildhaber still works for the police department.

A spokesman said the force was considering its options as regards an appeal, but St Louis County Exectuvie Sam Page says he now plans to appoint new staff to a police oversight board.
description: Sgt Keith Wildhaber was told that he needed to 'tone down his gayness' if he wanted a promotion, and successfully sued for discrimination as a result
